subject: Language Arts
title: Unlocking Figurative Language
learningObjectives: Define and identify similes, metaphors, and personification.
Interpret the meaning of figurative language in context.
Use figurative language in their own writing.

content.body: Figurative language makes writing more interesting and vivid. It uses words in a non-literal way to create a special effect or meaning.

content.alt: An icon representing different types of figurative language.

content.body: A simile compares two things using 'like' or 'as' (e.g., 'as brave as a lion'). A metaphor directly compares two things (e.g., 'The world is a stage'). Personification gives human qualities to objects or animals (e.g., 'The wind whispered through the trees').

questions.question: Which of the following is a simile?
options: He is as strong as an ox.
The sun smiled down on us.
questions.correctAnswer: He is as strong as an ox.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the metaphor 'The classroom was a zoo'?
options: The classroom was full of animals.
The classroom was very chaotic and noisy.
The classroom was clean and organized.
questions.correctAnswer: The classroom was very chaotic and noisy.

content.body: El lenguaje figurado hace que la escritura sea más interesante y vívida. Usa palabras de una manera no literal para crear un efecto o significado especial.

questions.question: ¿Cuál de los siguientes es un símil?
options: Es tan fuerte como un buey.

questions.question: ¿Cuál es el significado de la metáfora 'El aula era un zoológico'?
options: El aula estaba llena de animales.
El aula era muy caótica y ruidosa.
El aula estaba limpia y organizada.
